information: During the season, the Rockies' manager Bud Black was fired and replaced by Warren Schaeffer. Hitting coach Jordan Pacheco was also part of the new staff. On May 18, 2025, the team achieved a 14-12 comeback win against the Arizona Diamondbacks, which was their first victory under Schaeffer. A key contributor to this win was shortstop Ezequiel Tovar, who had recently returned from injury and went 5-for-5 with his first home run of the season. The team's upcoming schedule before June 15 included games against several high-performing teams.

forecast.status_quo_outcome: No — they are very likely in the bottom tier, but with multiple similarly poor teams, inertia favors a clustered bottom rather than a single clear-worst club by that specific date.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Rockies play roughly .400-.450 ball over the next ~25 games while one or two peers (e.g., White Sox/Marlins/A’s/Angels/Nationals) slump harder. Even modest improvement, combined with variance elsewhere, leaves another team alone at the bottom, or a tie forms that does not break against Colorado at the time the standings are checked.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Facing a tough pre–June 15 slate, the Rockies go something like 6–16, while other bottom teams hover closer to .350–.400. Colorado ends up with the lowest (or tied-lowest) winning percentage on June 15 when the MLB standings are checked.
forecast.rationale:
Starting point: This is a single-team, single-date “lowest winning percentage” event. Unconditionally, any specific team’s chance of being last on a given future date is low (~3–5%). Conditioning on early-season signals moves this higher.

Signals we have: The Rockies were bad enough by mid-May to fire Bud Black; Warren Schaeffer’s first win came May 18 after initial losses. That implies a very poor record to date, plausibly bottom 2–3. The research assistant also notes a difficult schedule up to June 15, which should depress short-term win rate. Tovar’s return and a one-game outburst help the lineup marginally but don’t materially change team quality in the near term.

Mechanics: From May 19 to June 15 the Rockies will play roughly 20–25 games. Short windows exhibit high variance, and several teams commonly inhabit the basement around this time of year. Even if Colorado is currently last or tied for last, leapfrogs are common over a 3–4 week span. If they are second- or third-worst right now, they still have a live path to “Yes” via a tough schedule and continued struggles. Conversely, any mild rebound or a worse slump from another cellar team leads to “No.”

Ties: MLB’s standings display winning percentage. If Colorado shares the lowest winning percentage, they still “have the lowest winning percentage” in the ordinary reading; I am assuming a tie counts as Yes unless the resolution notes require sole last. If a sole-last condition were required, I would lower my estimate a few points because ties at the bottom are common in mid-June.

Why not higher? There are typically multiple bottom-feeders (e.g., White Sox, Marlins, A’s, Angels/Nationals), and the probability any single one is the worst on that exact date stays below 50% absent a clear gap. Manager bumps and small-sample variance can move Colorado off the very bottom for a week or two.

Why not lower? The managerial change following a very poor start plus a tough forthcoming schedule increases the chance they remain or become the lowest by mid-June. Colorado has been structurally weak in recent seasons, so a sharp short-term turnaround is less likely than continued struggles.

What would move me up: Confirmed current standings showing Colorado already has the league’s worst (or tied-worst) percentage by a meaningful margin; injury setbacks to key Rockies pitchers/regulars; confirmation that the upcoming series are disproportionately against top-10 teams.

What would move me down: Evidence that one or two other teams are currently well below Colorado in winning percentage; a softer-than-expected Colorado schedule before June 15; indications of a material roster boost (multiple key returns) or sustained improved pitching metrics over the next two series.
